text: Welcome <@UFXFB1RK8> - came across this nice 'design language' model from ink & switch recently: <https://www.inkandswitch.com/capstone-manuscript-appendices.html#b-design-language>

elements.text: Welcome
- came across this nice 'design language' model from ink & switch recently:

text:
The aspect I find most appealing is having 'one portal' for all stuff. Currently I log into portal#1 (my laptop) - here I get my local files and apps only. One app (firefox) has me log in to portals 2, 3, 4 (gmail/gdrive, github, <http://futureofocoding.slack.com|futureofocoding.slack.com>) - each one completely siloed away - and has its own set of artifacts. I have various systems in place to sync and various rudimentary import/export mechanisms to move stuff around between these portals, and the nature of computing/programming is very different too.
On the web, every app is in fact a new portal to a new siloed world. I hope we have have one world where all artifacts are possible, can interlink etc and we can program here too.

text: One of the challenges of running a lab with a rotating cast has been establishing consistent use of jargon across projects. This is important, because it helps evolve a cohesive viewpoint within the group, but having a document like this helps with onboarding new people.

elements.text: One of the challenges of running a lab with a rotating cast has been establishing consistent use of jargon across projects. This is important, because it helps evolve a cohesive viewpoint within the group, but having a document like this helps with onboarding new people.

text: We operate under what we call the "Hollywood model", which is to say that we have a small standing group within the lab and bring on domain experts for each project -- an iOS developer, perhaps, or a security auditor -- but we definitely see dividends when we're able to work with the same folks more than once.

elements.text: We operate under what we call the "Hollywood model", which is to say that we have a small standing group within the lab and bring on domain experts for each project -- an iOS developer, perhaps, or a security auditor -- but we definitely see dividends when we're able to work with the same folks more than once.

text: I read the ACM article. Not sure that I fully grok the concept, but from what I can gather... it's a technique for orchestration. It feels vaguely similar to a rule system, or a constraint system, or a logic system, in that the programmer specifies what they do _and don't_ want to happen in a declarative way, and then an underlying engine uses some heuristics of varying sophistication to execute the specifications (or, alternatively, generate code that executes according to the specifications). The "_and don't_" is emphasized by Harel as a key advancement in this approach compared to (say) pub/sub.

want to happen in a declarative way, and then an underlying engine uses some heuristics of varying sophistication to execute the specifications (or, alternatively, generate code that executes according to the specifications). The "
and don't
" is emphasized by Harel as a key advancement in this approach compared to (say) pub/sub.

text: I got the _strong_ sense that this programming model does not scale well, and thus you need to lean on checkers and validators and other such _sufficiently smart compilers_ to avoid writing code that deadlocks or has unintended consequences.

elements.text: I got the
strong
sense that this programming model does not scale well, and thus you need to lean on checkers and validators and other such
sufficiently smart compilers
to avoid writing code that deadlocks or has unintended consequences.

text: It seems like a major design goal is to allow program behaviour to be specified incrementally, with something like a _dialogue_ taking place between the programmer and their program. Musing on this characteristic of their design was absolutely my favourite part of reading the article. I can easily imagine how their approach would work really well for early prototyping and exploring a behaviour space. I could see this being used in game dev to great effect, for scripting "AI" routines or PCG systems. This is probably going to be what I take away from BP, more than all the stuff in the middle about implementation hoops they had to jump through, or various attempts they made to get over some of the apparent shortcomings in the design.

text: They gave some examples and alluded to uses in industrial process control, including an example of individually controlling the motors in a quadcopter and a mention of controlling valves, pumps, etc. I cringed at these examples — Behavioral Programming seems well suited for discrete, digital "on/off" control in non-realtime use cases. Flying a quadcopter, or doing industrial process control, are cases where you typically want tight bounds on execution time, control over determinism, and semantics that allow for things like PID. The example of "Motors shouldn't have a speed below zero — if an event is going to reduce the speed below zero, block it" seems like far too blunt an instrument for these use cases.

Flying a quadcopter, or doing industrial process control, are cases where you typically want tight bounds on execution time, control over determinism, and semantics that allow for things like PID. The example of "Motors shouldn't have a speed below zero — if an event is going to reduce the speed below zero, block it" seems like far too blunt an instrument for these use cases.

text: Sure, you could probably have a subsystem that performs PID, and then orchestrate it and other subsystems using BP, but that wasn't the tack taken by the article.

elements.text: Sure, you could probably have a subsystem that performs PID, and then orchestrate it and other subsystems using BP, but that wasn't the tack taken by the article.

text: I'm going to read the paper on BP for animation, since animation is an area of specialization for me and I'm really quite curious to see how the hell they square these circles.

elements.text: I'm going to read the paper on BP for animation, since animation is an area of specialization for me and I'm really quite curious to see how the hell they square these circles.

text: Also, their Java implementation is called BPJ, which stands for "Peanut Butter Jelly" as far as I'm aware. At least, that's how I read it every time I saw the acronym.

elements.text: Also, their Java implementation is called BPJ, which stands for "Peanut Butter Jelly" as far as I'm aware. At least, that's how I read it every time I saw the acronym.

text: (Except for all those horrendously scarred C programmers who flip the order and do `constant == variable`, so that if they miss one of the equals signs, it's a compiler error rather than a nightmare to debug)

text: If a normalized notation was possible, it would be tremendously useful for a language like Unison that identifies functions by their hashes. I think even if it can't be done in general, having a consistent way to simplify / normalize notation could reduce the number of identical programs without eliminating the possibility for them.
